question: Question_02_(a)
statement:
Consider the following system of linear equations

\begin{align*}
2x-y+2z&=a\\
x+3y-6z&=b\\
3x+2y-4z&=c,
\end{align*}

where a,b, and c $\in\R$.

Write the system in matrix form $A\mathbf{x}=\mathbf{b}$. Clearly define
A, $\mathbf{b}$, and $\mathbf{x}$.
sols:
The matrix $\displaystyle A$ should be composed of the coefficients of
the variables on the left hand sides of the equations. Thus

$A = \begin{bmatrix}
2 & -1 & 2\\
1 & 3 & -6\\
3 & 2 & -4
\end{bmatrix}$

Next, we note that to compose the $\mathbf{x}$ on the right to the
matrix $\displaystyle A$. The right hand side has to be $\mathbf{b}$.
Thus

$\mathbf{x} = \begin{bmatrix} x \\ y \\ z \end{bmatrix} \quad \quad \mathbf{b} = \begin{bmatrix} a \\ b \\ c \end{bmatrix}$

As a sanity check, perform the matrix multiplication so that you can
verify that this works.
